Key Arguments: No entity can claim to have infinite knowledge or truth, making it impossible to definitively label information as misinformation or disinformation.
Humans are inherently fallible and biased, which can lead to mistakes in judgment about information.
Punitive measures against individuals or organizations based on controversial or conflicting data could lead to injustice.
Freedom of speech is a fundamental human right, and restricting it diminishes human dignity.
Truth often emerges from informed dialogue, which may initially involve misinformation or disinformation.
Historical examples in medical science show that accepted truths can change with new evidence, highlighting the fallibility of current knowledge.
Notable Quotes: No body or institution can ever claim to have infinite knowledge or truth about an issue.
It is a fundamental human right to have freedom of speech and any curtailment of this diminishes the stature of personhood.
It is only totalitarian states, imposing in a top-down approach, restrictions on what people want to express.
